universeFacts.fact: The observable universe is estimated to be 93 billion light-years in diameter, even though it's only 13.8 billion years old.
There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all the beaches on Earth - estimated at 10^24 stars.
A teaspoon of neutron star material would weigh about 6 billion tons on Earth.
Dark matter makes up about 27% of the universe, while ordinary matter only accounts for 5%.
The largest known structure in the universe is the Hercules-Corona Borealis Great Wall, spanning 10 billion light-years.
One day on Venus is longer than one year on Venus - it takes 243 Earth days to rotate once but only 225 Earth days to orbit the Sun.
Black holes can have temperatures, and the larger they are, the colder they get due to Hawking radiation.
The coldest place in the universe is the Boomerang Nebula at -458°F (-272°C), just 1 degree above absolute zero.
Jupiter's moon Europa has twice as much water as all of Earth's oceans combined, hidden beneath its icy surface.
The Sun converts 4 million tons of matter into energy every second through nuclear fusion.
Space is completely silent because sound waves need a medium to travel through, and space is a vacuum.
The Milky Way galaxy is on a collision course with the Andromeda galaxy, expected to merge in about 4.5 billion years.
A single solar flare can release the energy equivalent to billions of hydrogen bombs.
The universe is expanding at an accelerating rate, driven by mysterious dark energy.
Saturn's moon Titan has lakes and rivers of liquid methane and ethane instead of water.
The Great Red Spot on Jupiter is a storm that has been raging for at least 400 years and is larger than Earth.
Gamma-ray bursts are the most energetic explosions in the universe, releasing more energy in seconds than our Sun will in its entire lifetime.
The cosmic microwave background radiation is the afterglow of the Big Bang, still detectable today as a faint signal throughout space.
Magnetars are neutron stars with magnetic fields trillions of times stronger than Earth's, capable of warping the very atoms around them.
The farthest galaxy ever observed, GN-z11, appears as it was just 400 million years after the Big Bang.
If you could fold a piece of paper 42 times, it would reach the Moon. If you folded it 103 times, it would be thicker than the observable universe.
Proxima Centauri, our nearest star neighbor, would take over 70,000 years to reach with current technology.
The asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter contains less mass than Earth's Moon despite having millions of asteroids.
Quasars are so bright they can outshine entire galaxies while being powered by supermassive black holes.
The temperature at the core of the Sun is about 27 million degrees Fahrenheit (15 million Celsius) - 6 times hotter than the surface.
